content:
‚ö° TL;DR
git rebase -i HEAD~N or
git rebase -i <starting-commit-hash>^ git commit --amend --author="Name <email>" git rebase --continue git push --force ‚ö†Ô∏è Warning: Modifying commits that have already been pushed to a remote repository can cause history conflicts with collaborators. Use this only when working alone!
üìù Problem: Incorrect Git Author Information When working on the same GitHub repository across different computers (like work and personal), you might find that your commit author information gets mixed up.
In my case, I had set my company account’s name and email in the global configuration for convenience, and that’s where the trouble began.
As a result, my commits were being recorded with my company email, making it appear as if multiple people were contributing to the project.
I had to go through each commit to correct the author information and then update the history on GitHub. Here’s how I did it:
üß© Situation Summary Personal and company account information got mixed up in commits Wrong names appeared in GitHub Contributors Decided to clean up the commit history üõ†Ô∏è Solution Process 1. Select Commits with Interactive Rebase git rebase -i HEAD~N Or if you want to start rebasing from a specific commit:
git rebase -i abc1234^ The ^ symbol means “start rebasing from the commit before this one.”
Or if you want to rebase from the very first commit:
git rebase -i --root When the list appears, change pick to edit and save.
üí° Quick Edit Tip With cursor on pick: dw to delete pick ‚Üí i e to type just the ’e’ of edit (just ’e’ works too) In other words: move cursor, dw, i, e, then save (:wq) and you’re done!
2. Modify Author Information git commit --amend --author="New Name <newemail@example.com>" This command overwrites the author information for that specific commit with your specified name and email.
The author you set here only applies to this specific commit, so you don’t need to modify your global or local settings.
3. Continue the Rebase git rebase --continue After modifying one commit, use this command to move to the next one.
Repeat this process for all commits you want to fix.
4. Update GitHub git push origin +main Finally, you need to force push to update the remote repository with the new history.
+main is equivalent to --force and will overwrite the existing history.
üß≠ Conclusion After this experience, I removed all global settings.
Instead, I now manage name and email settings locally in .git/config for each project.
It’s a bit more work, but it’s a preventive measure to avoid repeating this mistake.
üóÇÔ∏è TMI
By the way… if you’ve already pushed commits to GitHub and they’ve registered you as a Contributor, fixing the commits won’t change the Contributor list.
I ended up deleting the repository and creating a new one… üòá
(This is really a last resort.)
This experience taught me how a small mistake can mess up your history.
I hope this guide helps if you find yourself in a similar situation.
üìö References
This post was written with reference to madplay’s blog.

A look into the motivation, technical stack, and UX design philosophy behind Hyper-Dir
üß© Why I Wanted a Better File Explorer The default Windows File Explorer is okay ‚Äî but as a developer, I kept running into limitations.
No tab support Poor keyboard navigation No built-in dual/multi-pane view Difficult to customize or extend Eventually, I asked myself:
‚ÄúWhat if I just built my own?‚Äù
üöÄ The Birth of Hyper-Dir That‚Äôs how Hyper-Dir was born.
Not just a file explorer, but one that‚Äôs developer-friendly, lightning fast, extensible, and keyboard-first.
Inspired by tools like VSCode.
Project Goals ‚úÖ Full keyboard navigation ‚úÖ Multiple panels & tabs ‚úÖ Plugin-based extensibility ‚úÖ Clean and intuitive UX ‚úÖ Native-like performance üõ† Why I Chose Rust, Tauri, and React ü¶Ä Rust I was drawn to Rust for its performance and memory safety.
Working with the file system, especially on Windows, requires low-level control ‚Äî and Rust gives that without sacrificing safety.
ü™ü Tauri Compared to Electron, Tauri is:
Lighter Faster More native-feeling Best of all, it plays beautifully with Rust.
‚öõÔ∏è React For the frontend, I went with React.
Fast development Huge ecosystem Well-suited for building extensible UI, like VSCode extensions üß† UI/UX Inspired by VSCode Hyper-Dir’s interface is heavily inspired by Visual Studio Code.
Sidebar ‚Üí Directory tree Tab bar ‚Üí Navigate multiple folders Main panel ‚Üí File list / preview Status bar ‚Üí Path info, selection details Shortcuts ‚Üí Ctrl+P, Ctrl+B, and more Developers are already familiar with VSCode.
A familiar layout means less friction and better usability.
üó∫ Roadmap Ahead Hyper-Dir is still early in development, but here‚Äôs what‚Äôs coming next:
Git integration & embedded terminal Custom plugin system Favorites and history Advanced filtering & fuzzy search Extended command palette üí¨ Closing Thoughts As a developer, building the tools I use every day is incredibly rewarding.
Hyper-Dir started as a way to solve my own pain points ‚Äî but I hope it becomes a helpful tool for others too.
Curious about the project or want to contribute?
Feedback, issues, and PRs are always welcome!
